title: Jeremiah Chapter 21 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 21 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 21 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 21.

questions.question: Who sent Pashur and Zephaniah to Jeremiah according to Jeremiah 21:1?
options: King Zedekiah
King Nebuchadrezzar
The priest Maaseiah
The prophet Jeremiah
questions.correctAnswer: King Zedekiah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:1 states that King Zedekiah sent Pashur and Zephaniah to Jeremiah.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 21:2, why did they ask Jeremiah to inquire of the LORD?
options: Because Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon was making war against them
Because they wanted to build a temple
Because they wanted to find a new king
Because they were preparing a feast
questions.correctAnswer: Because Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon was making war against them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:2 clearly states they asked because Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon was making war against them.

questions.question: What did the LORD say He would do with the weapons of war in Jeremiah 21:4?
options: Turn them back into the city
Destroy them completely
Give them to Nebuchadrezzar
Hide them outside the city
questions.correctAnswer: Turn them back into the city
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:4 states that the LORD will turn back the weapons of war into the midst of the city.

questions.question: How will God fight against the people according to Jeremiah 21:5?
options: With an outstretched hand, strong arm, anger, fury, and wrath
With peace and mercy
Through angels only
By sending a flood
questions.correctAnswer: With an outstretched hand, strong arm, anger, fury, and wrath
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:5 describes God's fight with outstretched hand, strong arm, anger, fury, and great wrath.

questions.question: What will happen to the inhabitants of the city according to Jeremiah 21:6?
options: They shall die of a great pestilence
They shall be taken captive
They shall be spared
They shall flee to the mountains
questions.correctAnswer: They shall die of a great pestilence
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:6 states that both man and beast shall die of a great pestilence.

questions.question: Who will deliver Zedekiah and the people into the hand of Nebuchadrezzar according to Jeremiah 21:7?
options: The LORD
The Egyptians
The Assyrians
The Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:7 says the LORD will deliver Zedekiah, his servants, and the people into Nebuchadrezzar's hand.

questions.question: What does the LORD set before the people in Jeremiah 21:8?
options: The way of life and the way of death
The way of peace and the way of war
The way of riches and the way of poverty
The way of prophecy and the way of silence
questions.correctAnswer: The way of life and the way of death
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:8 states the LORD sets before them the way of life and the way of death.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 21:9, what will happen to those who stay in the city?
options: They shall die by the sword, famine, and pestilence
They shall be saved and prosper
They shall be taken to Egypt
They shall build stronger walls
questions.correctAnswer: They shall die by the sword, famine, and pestilence
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:9 warns that those abiding in the city will die by sword, famine, and pestilence.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 21:10 says the city will be given into Nebuchadrezzar's hand to be burned with fire.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:10 states clearly that the city will be delivered to the king of Babylon and burned with fire.

questions.question: Who is addressed in Jeremiah 21:12 with a call to execute judgment and deliver the oppressed?
options: House of David
The priests
The prophets
The people of Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: House of David
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:12 addresses the house of David with instructions to execute judgment and rescue the oppressed.

questions.question: What will happen if the house of David does not deliver the oppressed, according to Jeremiah 21:12?
options: God's fury will burn like an unquenchable fire
They will be blessed
They will be rewarded with peace
The city will prosper
questions.correctAnswer: God's fury will burn like an unquenchable fire
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:12 warns that failing to deliver the oppressed will cause God's fury to burn like a fire none can quench.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 21:13 mentions the inhabitants asking 'Who shall come down against us?'
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:13 states that the inhabitants say, 'Who shall come down against us? or who shall enter into our habitations?'

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 21:14, what will the LORD do as punishment?
options: Kindle a fire in the forest to devour all things
Send a flood to cleanse the land
Raise up a new king
Bless the fields with rain
questions.correctAnswer: Kindle a fire in the forest to devour all things
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:14 says the LORD will kindle a fire in the forest to devour all things around it as punishment.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Jeremiah 21:9: 'He that goeth out, and falleth to the Chaldeans that besiege you, he shall live, and his life shall be unto him for a ______.'
options: prey
treasure
reward
prize
questions.correctAnswer: prey
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:9 states that those who go out to the Chaldeans will live and their life shall be unto them for a prey.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 21:7 says Nebuchadrezzar will have pity and mercy on the people.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:7 says Nebuchadrezzar will not spare, have pity, nor have mercy on them.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 21 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 21 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear about facing hardships and enemies. Based on Jeremiah 21:4-5, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God's power in difficult times?
options: God will fight against our enemies with great wrath and strong arm
God will abandon us in our battles
We must rely solely on our own strength to overcome
God promises immediate peace without conflict
questions.correctAnswer: God will fight against our enemies with great wrath and strong arm
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:4-5 shows that God promises to fight against the enemies with a strong arm and great wrath, teaching us to trust in His power rather than fear hardships.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 21:8 teach us about making choices rooted in biblical wisdom?
options: God sets before us the way of life and the way of death
We should follow the crowd regardless of the outcome
Choices have no real spiritual consequence
Only worldly success matters
questions.correctAnswer: God sets before us the way of life and the way of death
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:8 teaches that God clearly presents us with the way of life and the way of death, emphasizing the importance of choosing obedience and faithfulness for true life.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to stay in a spiritually harmful environment. Based on Jeremiah 21:9, what counsel about perseverance and wisdom would you give?
options: Leaving the harmful environment to seek God's protection brings life
Staying will guarantee safety and blessing
Ignoring warnings leads to spiritual growth
Enduring harm is always the best test of faith
questions.correctAnswer: Leaving the harmful environment to seek God's protection brings life
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:9 states those who stay in the city will die by sword, famine, and pestilence, but those who go out to the besiegers will live, teaching the importance of wise decisions for preserving life.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 21:12, how should believers demonstrate integrity and justice in family and community life?
options: Execute judgment and deliver the oppressed to avoid God's wrath
Ignore injustice to maintain peace
Favor the strong and wealthy always
Delay justice for personal gain
questions.correctAnswer: Execute judgment and deliver the oppressed to avoid God's wrath
questions.explanation: Verse 12 emphasizes the call to execute judgment and deliver the oppressed, showing that integrity and justice are essential to avoid the consuming fire of God's anger.

questions.question: What biblical principle about humility and contentment can be drawn from Jeremiah 21:13-14 when facing false security?
options: Trusting in false security invites God’s punishment
Self-confidence protects from harm
Ignoring God’s warnings leads to blessing
Security comes from wealth and power
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting in false security invites God’s punishment
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:13-14 warns against false confidence in safety, teaching humility and reliance on God rather than self or worldly defenses.

questions.question: Based on Jeremiah 21:7, how does the passage teach about God’s justice and the consequences of disobedience?
options: God will deliver the remnant into the hand of their enemies without mercy
God will protect everyone equally without consequence
Disobedience is overlooked by God
God rewards disobedience with blessings
questions.correctAnswer: God will deliver the remnant into the hand of their enemies without mercy
questions.explanation: Verse 7 details how God will hand over Zedekiah and the people to their enemies without mercy due to their disobedience, illustrating God’s just consequences.

questions.question: A person is uncertain whether to pray for deliverance during trials. What does Jeremiah 21:2 teach about seeking God through prayer?
options: We should faithfully inquire of the LORD for help in times of war and distress
Prayer is unnecessary when facing enemies
God does not respond to requests in hardship
Seeking worldly help is better than seeking God
questions.correctAnswer: We should faithfully inquire of the LORD for help in times of war and distress
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:2 records a request to inquire of the LORD during war, showing the importance of turning to God in prayer during trials.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 21:10 counsel believers about the reality of trials and trusting God's plan?
options: God may set His face against us for discipline, not for our good
Trials indicate God's abandonment
God always promises ease and comfort
We can ignore God's warnings
questions.correctAnswer: God may set His face against us for discipline, not for our good
questions.explanation: Verse 10 teaches that God might bring evil rather than good as discipline, encouraging believers to trust His sovereign plan even in hardship.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 21:6 teaches that God will spare the inhabitants of the city from pestilence.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:6 states that God will smite the inhabitants with a great pestilence, showing that He does not spare them due to their disobedience.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 21:11-12 instructs the house of David to act justly and deliver those oppressed to avoid God's anger.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 11-12 clearly call the house of David to execute justice and rescue the oppressed, warning that failure will provoke God's consuming fury.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 21:9 says, 'He that abideth in this city shall die by the sword, and by the famine, and by the ________.'
options: pestilence
fire
flood
darkness
questions.correctAnswer: pestilence
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:9 mentions that those who remain will die by the sword, famine, and pestilence, emphasizing the serious consequences of disobedience.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 21:1-3 teach about seeking God's guidance in leadership and decision-making?
options: Leaders should inquire of the LORD for direction especially in crises
Leaders should rely on their own wisdom only
God's guidance is unnecessary in war
Decisions should be made quickly without consulting God
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders should inquire of the LORD for direction especially in crises
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:1-3 shows King Zedekiah sending men to Jeremiah to inquire of God, illustrating the importance of seeking God's guidance in leadership.

questions.question: From Jeremiah 21:14, how should believers understand the consequences of their actions in relation to God's discipline?
options: God will punish according to the fruit of their doings, like a fire devouring a forest
Actions have no impact on divine discipline
God favors those who do evil
Discipline is random and unrelated to behavior
questions.correctAnswer: God will punish according to the fruit of their doings, like a fire devouring a forest
questions.explanation: Verse 14 makes clear that God’s punishment corresponds to their deeds, illustrating divine justice through the metaphor of a consuming fire.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 21:5 encourage believers to trust in God’s power rather than their own efforts during trials?
options: God Himself will fight against the people with outstretched hand and strong arm
Human strength alone is sufficient for victory
Ignoring God leads to success
Trials will be avoided by human tactics
questions.correctAnswer: God Himself will fight against the people with outstretched hand and strong arm
questions.explanation: Verse 5 emphasizes that God will actively fight with great power against the disobedient, teaching reliance on His strength rather than human effort.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 21:7, what attitude should believers have toward God's justice when facing consequences for sin?
options: Accept that God’s justice may be severe and without pity
Expect to be spared regardless of actions
Doubt that God punishes sin
Ignore God's warnings about judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Accept that God’s justice may be severe and without pity
questions.explanation: Verse 7 shows God will hand over the people to their enemies without mercy, teaching believers to accept His just discipline even when severe.

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 21 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 21.

questions.question: Who did King Zedekiah send to Jeremiah to inquire of the LORD about the Babylonian threat?
options: Pashur the son of Melchiah and Zephaniah the son of Maaseiah
Eliakim the son of Hilkiah and Gedaliah the son of Pashhur
Jeremiah himself and Baruch his scribe
Nebuchadrezzar and his chief officers
questions.correctAnswer: Pashur the son of Melchiah and Zephaniah the son of Maaseiah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:1 states that King Zedekiah sent Pashur the son of Melchiah and Zephaniah the son of Maaseiah to Jeremiah to enquire of the LORD.

questions.question: What specific request did Zedekiah's envoys make to Jeremiah regarding the LORD's response?
options: To inquire if the LORD will remove Nebuchadrezzar from them
To ask if the LORD will grant them victory in battle
To seek a sign from the LORD about the future
To ask the LORD for immediate deliverance by fire
questions.correctAnswer: To inquire if the LORD will remove Nebuchadrezzar from them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:2 shows they asked Jeremiah to enquire of the LORD if Nebuchadrezzar would go up from them, reflecting a hope for relief from siege.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah's message, what will happen to the weapons of war in the hands of Judah's people?
options: They will be turned back into the city
They will be blessed for victory
They will be broken and discarded
They will be given to the Babylonians
questions.correctAnswer: They will be turned back into the city
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:4 states that the LORD will turn back the weapons of war into the midst of the city, indicating defeat rather than victory.

questions.question: What is the nature of God's fight against Jerusalem as described in Jeremiah 21?
options: With an outstretched hand, strong arm, anger, fury, and great wrath
With gentle correction and restoration
Through peaceful prophets and dreams
By sending foreign allies to protect them
questions.correctAnswer: With an outstretched hand, strong arm, anger, fury, and great wrath
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:5 describes God's fight against the city with powerful wrath and anger, highlighting divine judgment rather than protection.

questions.question: What calamities does God declare He will bring upon the inhabitants of the city?
options: Pestilence causing death of man and beast
Famine only
Exile without destruction
Flood and earthquake
questions.correctAnswer: Pestilence causing death of man and beast
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:6 states that God will smite both man and beast with a great pestilence, indicating total devastation.

questions.question: What fate awaits King Zedekiah and those left in the city after the pestilence?
options: They will be delivered into the hand of Nebuchadrezzar and enemies without mercy
They will be spared and allowed to remain
They will be taken captive to Egypt
They will be secretly rescued by the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: They will be delivered into the hand of Nebuchadrezzar and enemies without mercy
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:7 prophesies that Zedekiah and survivors will be handed over to Babylonian forces who will show no pity or mercy.

questions.question: What two ways does the LORD set before the people according to Jeremiah's message?
options: The way of life and the way of death
The way of conquest and the way of surrender
The way of exile and the way of peace
The way of darkness and the way of light
questions.correctAnswer: The way of life and the way of death
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:8 clearly states the LORD sets before them the way of life and death, emphasizing a choice with eternal consequences.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 21, what will happen to those who stay in the city?
options: They shall die by sword, famine, and pestilence
They shall be victorious against Babylon
They shall be taken safely to exile
They shall live in peace under Babylonian rule
questions.correctAnswer: They shall die by sword, famine, and pestilence
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:9 states those who remain in the city will die by sword, famine, and pestilence, highlighting the inevitability of judgment.

questions.question: What assurance is given to those who surrender to the Chaldeans besieging Jerusalem?
options: They shall live, and their life shall be for a prey
They shall be killed immediately
They will be enslaved without hope
They will be sent away to distant lands
questions.correctAnswer: They shall live, and their life shall be for a prey
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:9 promises life to those who go out to the Chaldeans, indicating survival through surrender.

questions.question: What is the LORD's declared attitude towards Jerusalem in this chapter?
options: Set against it for evil, not for good
Ready to forgive and restore
Neutral and observing
Protective and comforting
questions.correctAnswer: Set against it for evil, not for good
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:10 explicitly states the LORD has set His face against the city for evil, underscoring divine judgment.

questions.question: What instruction is given specifically to the house of David regarding justice?
options: Execute judgment in the morning and deliver the spoiled from oppressors
Ignore injustice and focus on rituals
Build stronger walls for protection
Send envoys to Babylon for peace talks
questions.correctAnswer: Execute judgment in the morning and deliver the spoiled from oppressors
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:12 instructs the house of David to practice justice promptly and protect the oppressed to avoid the LORD's burning fury.

questions.question: What warning accompanies the command to execute judgment and deliver the oppressed?
options: Lest the LORD's fury burn uncontrollably like fire
Or the city will be destroyed by flood
Or the king will lose his throne
Or the Babylonians will be defeated
questions.correctAnswer: Lest the LORD's fury burn uncontrollably like fire
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:12 warns that failure to act justly will provoke the LORD's wrath, which will burn like an unquenchable fire.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 21:13, what false confidence do the inhabitants express that God condemns?
options: Who shall come down against us or enter our habitations?
We will defeat the Babylonians with our armies
Our gods will protect us from harm
We shall never be taken captive
questions.correctAnswer: Who shall come down against us or enter our habitations?
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:13 highlights the inhabitants' arrogant question which God condemns as false security.

questions.question: What metaphor does the LORD use to describe the coming punishment in Jeremiah 21:14?
options: A fire kindled in the forest that devours all around
A flood that sweeps the plains
A storm that uproots trees
A sword that cuts like lightning
questions.correctAnswer: A fire kindled in the forest that devours all around
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:14 uses the metaphor of a consuming forest fire to symbolize God's consuming judgment.

questions.question: True or False: According to Jeremiah 21, those who surrender to the Babylonians will be spared and live.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:9 states that those who go out to the Chaldeans (Babylonians) shall live, indicating survival through surrender.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 21 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 21 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: Who sent Pashur and Zephaniah to Jeremiah to inquire of the LORD during the Babylonian siege?
options: King Zedekiah
King Nebuchadnezzar
Prophet Jeremiah
Priest Maaseiah
questions.correctAnswer: King Zedekiah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:1 states that King Zedekiah sent Pashur and Zephaniah to Jeremiah to enquire of the LORD. This reflects the king's reliance on prophetic guidance, similar to David seeking God's counsel (1 Samuel 23:2) and Hezekiah seeking Isaiah's prophecy (2 Kings 19:2).

questions.question: What was the specific request King Zedekiah made through his envoys to Jeremiah?
options: To ask if the LORD would withdraw the Babylonian army
To ask for military aid from Egypt
To inquire about the rebuilding of the temple
To receive a sign from heaven
questions.correctAnswer: To ask if the LORD would withdraw the Babylonian army
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:2 records the request to inquire if the LORD will deal with them according to His wondrous works and remove Nebuchadnezzar's army. This reflects the biblical theme of seeking divine intervention in times of crisis (Exodus 14:13, 2 Chronicles 20:12).

questions.question: According to Jeremiah's message, how will God respond to the weapons of war held by the people?
options: God will turn the weapons back into the city
God will multiply the weapons for defense
God will bless the weapons with victory
God will hide the weapons in the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: God will turn the weapons back into the city
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:4 explains God will turn back the weapons of war into the city itself, signifying judgment rather than protection. This is consistent with God's sovereign control over instruments of war (Psalm 46:9, Isaiah 10:5-6).

questions.question: What is the nature of God's fight against the people as described in this chapter?
options: With an outstretched hand, strong arm, anger, fury, and great wrath
With gentle mercy and forgiveness
With silence and withdrawal
With angelic armies and thunder
questions.correctAnswer: With an outstretched hand, strong arm, anger, fury, and great wrath
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:5 describes God's active and intense judgment against the people, highlighting His holiness and righteous anger (Nahum 1:2, Romans 1:18). This reflects God's justice in punishing sin.

questions.question: What calamities does God say will come upon the inhabitants of the city?
options: Death by great pestilence affecting both man and beast
Blessings and prosperity
Peace and safety
Exile without death
questions.correctAnswer: Death by great pestilence affecting both man and beast
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:6 pronounces that both man and beast shall die from a great pestilence, illustrating the comprehensive nature of divine judgment (Exodus 9:3, Ezekiel 14:21).

questions.question: What ultimate fate does God declare for King Zedekiah and those left in the city?
options: Delivered into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar and their enemies without mercy
Guaranteed safe passage to another land
Given victory over Babylon
Protected by angelic hosts
questions.correctAnswer: Delivered into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar and their enemies without mercy
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:7 states that Zedekiah and the survivors will be handed over to Babylon and their enemies who will show no mercy, affirming the certainty of judgment and the consequences of rebellion (2 Kings 25:7, Lamentations 4:20).

questions.question: What two paths does God set before the people according to Jeremiah?
options: The way of life and the way of death
The way of riches and the way of poverty
The way of peace and the way of war
The way of exile and the way of return
questions.correctAnswer: The way of life and the way of death
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:8 declares God sets before them the way of life and death, emphasizing the moral and spiritual choice inherent in God's covenant relationship (Deuteronomy 30:15, Joshua 24:15, John 14:6).

questions.question: What is the promise for those who leave the city and surrender to the Chaldeans?
options: They shall live and their life shall be for a prey
They shall be executed immediately
They shall be sold into slavery
They shall be exiled to Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: They shall live and their life shall be for a prey
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:9 promises life for those who surrender to the Chaldeans, showing God's provision for survival through submission, echoing themes of repentance and mercy (2 Chronicles 20:30, Isaiah 1:18).

questions.question: What is the LORD's declared intention toward the city?
options: To bring evil, not good, and hand it to Babylon to burn
To protect it from all harm
To restore it to its former glory
To make it a holy city forever
questions.correctAnswer: To bring evil, not good, and hand it to Babylon to burn
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:10 states God's face is set against the city for evil, not good, resulting in destruction by fire at Babylon's hands. This underscores God's righteous judgment on persistent sin (Isaiah 1:7, Ezekiel 22:31).

questions.question: What is the charge given to the house of David regarding justice?
options: Execute judgment in the morning and deliver the oppressed
Build a stronger army
Seek alliances with foreign nations
Ignore the poor and weak
questions.correctAnswer: Execute judgment in the morning and deliver the oppressed
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:12 commands the house of David to practice justice and rescue the oppressed to prevent God's uncontrollable wrath, reinforcing the biblical mandate for justice (Isaiah 1:17, Micah 6:8, Proverbs 31:8-9).

questions.question: What metaphor does God use to describe His impending judgment on the valley inhabitants?
options: A fire kindled in the forest that devours all
A flood that covers the land
A storm that uproots the trees
A lion that hunts the prey
questions.correctAnswer: A fire kindled in the forest that devours all
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:14 uses the metaphor of a consuming fire in the forest to illustrate the comprehensive and unstoppable nature of God's judgment, similar to imagery in Isaiah 9:18 and Ezekiel 20:47.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 21, what does the LORD say about those who remain inside the city during the siege?
options: They shall die by sword, famine, and pestilence
They shall be protected by angels
They shall escape unharmed
They shall be rescued by foreign allies
questions.correctAnswer: They shall die by sword, famine, and pestilence
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:9 clearly warns that those who stay in the city will die from sword, famine, and pestilence, reflecting the consequences of rejecting God's warnings (Psalm 91:5-6, Ezekiel 5:12).

questions.question: What attitude does God express toward the city’s inhabitants who ask, 'Who shall come down against us?'
options: God declares He is against them and will punish them
God promises to protect them
God ignores their question
God encourages their confidence
questions.correctAnswer: God declares He is against them and will punish them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:13 reveals God's opposition to the inhabitants who presumptuously question who will attack, demonstrating His righteous judgment on false security (Proverbs 1:24-31, Isaiah 10:5-7).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah convey the LORD’s message about the siege weapons in the hands of the people?
options: They will be turned back into the city itself, intensifying their judgment
They will bring victory over the Babylonians
They will be hidden by angels
They will be blessed for protection
questions.correctAnswer: They will be turned back into the city itself, intensifying their judgment
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 21:4 states that God will turn the weapons in their hands back into the city, symbolizing that their own efforts will cause their downfall, echoing themes in Judges 7:22 and Isaiah 31:1.

questions.question: What divine attribute is most clearly displayed by God's pronouncement of judgment in Jeremiah 21?
options: God's justice and wrath against sin
God's patience without limit
God's indifference to human affairs
God's unconditional blessing
questions.correctAnswer: God's justice and wrath against sin
questions.explanation: The chapter emphasizes God's justice and righteous wrath (Jeremiah 21:5-7), consistent with Old and New Testament teachings about God's holiness and judgment (Romans 1:18, Hebrews 10:30, Psalm 7:11).
